EU Battlegroups are multinational, military units, with at least 1500 personnel each and form an integral part of the European Union's military rapid reaction capacity to respond to emerging crises and conflicts around the world. The European Union Battlegroup is the EU's Rapid Response Force and can be deployed in a radius of up to 6,000 km around Brussels. The EUBG concept forms the basis for the EU's rapid crisis response and is intended to ensure the strategic independence of the European Union. They permit the EU and its Member states to respond early and rapidly to evolving conflicts. Preventing conflicts and engaging at an early stage is more efficient and effective than engaging at a later stage in fully fledged violent conflicts. In conjunction with a reliable early warning system, EU Battlegroups permit a targeted and rapid response to minimise human suffering and insecurity. In a world of predictable unpredictability, reacting fast is at times the only way to react effectively. While Member States remain in the driving seat and are responsible for deploying security and armed forces when needed, the EU can facilitate and reinforce this cooperation and make the collective effort more effective. Ensuring a joined-up and comprehensive approach which makes full use of all the EU's available instruments and acts on all stages and levels of the conflict is essential to achieve a lasting resolution of violent conflicts and crises. Greece is a peaceful nation, we don’t support war especially with allied powers, the only time Greece will go to war with Turkey is if Turkey attacks us first BUT! the North Atlantic Treaty (the treaty on the formation of NATO) states on Article 5 that: “An armed attack on one member state is an attack on all’’ which means that if Turkey dares to declare war, Greece has the right to invoke article 5, and then Turkey will be at war with 29 countries instead of just one. Also, Greece, as a member of the EU is also protected by another 6 non-NATO countries so that raises the number of allies to 35 (Based on the Treaty of Lisbon: Mutual Defense Clause). Also, Turkey’s relations with Russia couldn't be described as the best, so another possible ally is Russia cause they wouldn’t let Turkey control the Eastern Med. Then Russia is a member of the CSTO (Collective Security Treaty Organization) in which Armenia, a neighboring country of Turkey is also a member of. Then we have the EastMed Gas Pipeline, why this is important? Because in the agreement, there is an article which states that “the pipeline shall be protected by any means” which also means by the military. So this means that Turkey will also have to face Israel, a tiny nation yet one of the strongest. So tell me, please, would Turkey really risk a world war with 42 strong nations?
